a: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
d: We hypothesized that melanoma cells hijack neuronal mechanisms to allow them to invade into the mechanically confined microenvironment
e: Neuronal development relies on microtubule (MT) architecture (Ref: 14) ... Recent reports indicate that the MT cytoskeleton is stabilized by force to protect confined cells from damage (Ref: 16)
f: We used our in vitro confinement system to characterize how force remodels the MT cytoskeleton by imaging A375 cells labelled with the MT vital dye SiR-tubulin

a: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
d: Confinement extensively remodelled the MT cytoskeleton; within 2-4 h, curved MTs began encircling the cell and nuclear periphery (Fig. 2a,b)
e: This was reminiscent of a previous study that showed that MTs bend to prevent buckling or rupture in response to force (Ref: 16)
f: (missing)

a: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
d: We also observed loss of a central MT organizing centre with radial MTs
e: reminiscent of neurons with centrosome-independent MT organization (Ref: 14,17)
f: These results indicate that confined melanoma cells rapidly undergo structural changes in the MT cytoskeleton resembling neurons

a: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma

e: Acetylated tubulin mediates neuronal architecture and function and marks axonal MTs (Ref: 18). Tubulin acetylation stabilizes MTs and thus the cell against mechanical pressure (Ref: 19)

a: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
d: Although confined perinuclear MTs were occasionally tyrosinated and rarely detyrosinated (Extended Data Fig. 4a-d), there was no specific enrichment of these PTMs in the perinuclear network, as observed for acetylated MTs. Similar results were observed for polyglutamylated MTs (Extended Data Fig. 4e,f). No polyglycylated MTs were found in either condition (Extended Data Fig. 4g,h)
f: This indicates that acetylation is the primary PTM mediating the assembly and/or stability of the perinuclear tubulin network. These data indicate that confined melanoma cells assemble a stable perinuclear tubulin network to reinforce the nucleus against mechanical stress, similar to neurons.

d: We then tested the role of HMGB2 in drug tolerance in vivo
f: by transplanting human melanoma cells overexpressing HMGB2 into athymic mice and treating the resulting tumours with dabrafenib and trametinib

a: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
B: HMGB2 is associated with drug tolerance
d: HMGB2 overexpression significantly impaired melanoma response to dabrafenib/trametinib in vivo (P = 0.043; Fig. 5o, Extended Data Fig. 13e and Supplementary Table 10)
f: Together, our results support a role for confinement-mediated upregulation of HMGB2 inducing a pro-invasive and drug-tolerant state in melanoma (Extended Data Fig. 15)
